newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentine Congress to raise income, not wealth tax.
newsitem.headline: Argentine Congress to raise income, not wealth tax.

text.p: The president of the Budget and Finance Committee of Argentina's lower house of Congress said Wednesday that the proposed hike in the wealth tax would be replaced by a rise in income tax.
"Personally I like much more the income tax because of its progressive scale and because it places a tax on revenues not on capital," said Oscar Lamberto of the ruling Peronist Party.
"We will have to collect the same amount in income as from the wealth tax," he said.
The proposed doubling of the wealth tax to 1.0 percent, opposed by President Carlos Menem and the business community, would reap the same revenue as a 10 percent rise in income tax, Lamberto said.
A 10 percent increment in the income tax is estimated to raise revenue by $600 million per year, as total proceeds from that levy now amount to $6.0 billion.
It was unclear whether the increase in income tax would be applied across the board or only to higher-income earners.
Economy Minister Roque Fernandez and Peronist legislators tried Tuesday to iron out differences over Fernandez's fiscal austerity package, submitted to Congress a week ago.

Fernandez hopes to narrow a fiscal deficit which he warns could hit $6.6 billion this year without the measures. He had hoped to boost the budget by $1.6 billion, but the package is being delayed and the bill to be debated first by the deputies has been watered down by the budget committee.

Fernandez and Menem opposed the proposed doubling of the wealth tax to 1.0 percent which was a concession won by lawmakers to compensate the provinces for lost revenues from other changes in the tax structure.
Menem pledged this week he would not allow any measures that scare off capital.
